question.title: Frog Jump
question.content:
Given an integer array height[] where height[i] represents the height of the i-th stair, a frog starts from the first stair and wants to reach the top. From any stair i, the frog has two options: it can either jump to the (i+1)th stair or the (i+2)th stair. The cost of a jump is the absolute difference in height between the two stairs. Determine the minimum total cost required for the frog to reach the top.

Example:

Input: heights[] = [20, 30, 40, 20] 
Output: 20
Explanation:  Minimum cost is incurred when the frog jumps from stair 0 to 1 then 1 to 3:
jump from stair 0 to 1: cost = |30 - 20| = 10
jump from stair 1 to 3: cost = |20-30|  = 10
Total Cost = 10 + 10 = 20
Input: heights[] = [30, 20, 50, 10, 40]
Output: 30
Explanation: Minimum cost will be incurred when frog jumps from stair 0 to 2 then 2 to 4:
jump from stair 0 to 2: cost = |50 - 30| = 20
jump from stair 2 to 4: cost = |40-50|  = 10
Total Cost = 20 + 10 = 30

Constraints:

  • 1 <= height.size() <= 105
  • 0 <= height[i]<=104

rephrased.body: A frog is attempting to reach the top of a staircase. Given an integer array `heights`, where `heights[i]` represents the height of the i-th stair, the frog starts at the first stair (index 0).  From any stair `i`, the frog can jump to either the `(i+1)`th stair or the `(i+2)`th stair. The cost of a jump is the absolute difference in height between the two stairs. Determine the minimum total cost for the frog to reach the last stair.

testcases.explanation: The minimum cost is achieved by jumping from stair 0 to stair 1 (cost |30-20| = 10) and then from stair 1 to stair 3 (cost |20-30| = 10). Total cost: 10 + 10 = 20.
The minimum cost is achieved by jumping from stair 0 to stair 2 (cost |50-30| = 20) and then from stair 2 to stair 4 (cost |40-50| = 10). Total cost: 20 + 10 = 30.

py.full_func:
#Back-end complete function Template for Python 3
class Solution:

    def minCost(self, height):
        n = len(height)

        # Base cases
        if n == 1:
            return 0
        if n == 2:
            return abs(height[0] - height[1])

        # Initialize variables to store the minimum energy for the two previous stairs
        prev2 = 0
        prev = abs(height[0] - height[1])
        curr = 0

        # Iterate through the stairs starting from the third stair
        for i in range(2, n):
            # Calculate energy if jumping from the (i-1)th stair
            jump1 = prev + abs(height[i - 1] - height[i])

            # Calculate energy if jumping from the (i-2)th stair
            jump2 = prev2 + abs(height[i - 2] - height[i])

            # Choose the minimum of the two possible jumps
            curr = min(jump1, jump2)

            # Update the previous two stairs for the next iteration
            prev2 = prev
            prev = curr

        return curr
